dc:title: Revegetation of artificial disturbances in grasslands of the Serengeti National Park, Tanzania. I. Colonization of grazed and ungrazed plots.
dc:creator: Belsky A.
dc:description: All species that grew in the physically disturbed plots were present prior to the treatments and, in most cases, the most abundant colonizing species were previously abundant also. Seedlings were more abundant than vegetative sprouts and ramets on disturbed plots. Densities of seedlings, sprouts and invading ramets decreased along a gradient of increasing rainfall and soil moisture. This decrease in revegetating plants was not correlated with soil type, persistent seed bank (which was negligible in all sites), or frequency of disturbance, but it was partially correlated with the composition of the undisturbed vegetation. Depth of disturbance affected significantly 28% of the species; seedlings were more abundant in the deeply disturbed and sprouting species were more abundant in shallowly disturbed plots. Grazing affected significantly 23% of the species. Most species escaped the effects of grazing by being prostrate, resprouting from ground-level or underground organs, or by growing before or after the periods of heaviest grazing. Large mammals were not responsible for the rich community pattern found in most Serengeti grasslands.-from Author

dc:title: Influence of population structure on self-thinning of plant populations.
dc:creator: Westoby M.
dc:description: Concludes that population structure is not an important influence on self-thinning paths relative to unexplained variation among stands. The mean slopes of the paths followed by the controls were less than the expected -1/2. The overall pattern of the results was consistent with the idea that paths are bounded by a line of slope -1/2 only up to some maximum biomass, after which density may continue to decline but biomass per unit area does not increase. During thinning, stands with different initial structures converged towards a frequency distribution of log weights which was roughly symmetrical and about 2-3 orders of magnitude broad.-from Authors

dc:title: Performance of Salix herbacea in an alpine snow-bed gradient.
dc:creator: Wijk S.
dc:description: Salix herbacea showed maximum cover, biomass and shoot density in the lowermost section of the topographical gradient where snow persisted for the longest period. Maxima in size and growth of individual shoots were found at the upper distributional limit. Low competitive ability might explain why this species is restricted to areas with severe climatic conditions. Lower average shoot age and absence of shoots over 10 years old in the upper part of the transect indicate a higher mortality rate, probably due to competition and herbivore damage. Within the transect, a 20% increase in growing season length was associated with a 5-fold increase in S. herbacea shoot growth. -from Author

dc:title: Small-scale heterogeneity in the seed bank of an acid grassland.
dc:creator: Thompson K.
dc:description: In acidic grassland on Dartmoor, Devon, Agrostis capillaris and Danthonia decumbens were the major species in the seed bank. Agrostis was also common in the vegetation but Danthonia was absent. Festuca ovina was frequent in the vegetation but absent from the seed bank.-from Author

dc:title: Changes in the composition and standing crop of salt-marsh communities in response to the removal of a grazer.
dc:creator: Bazely D.
dc:description: Changes in species composition, live standing crop and plant litter were measured in a saltmarsh at La Perouse Bay, Manitoba in the presence of lesser snow goose Anser c. caerulescens and when the grazer is excluded. After 5 yr, 16 species of higher plants were present in the oldest exclosure compared with 6 species in an adjacent (control) grazed area. Dicotyledons, such as Potentilla egedii and Plantago maritima, increased in frequency in the absence of grazing, and Carex subspathacea replaced Puccinellia phryganodes as the dominant graminoid. Within a season the standing crop of vegetation was highest in exclosures erected 1-2 yr previously. Litter accumulation in exclosures. The ratio of maximum standing crop to litter fell from >4:1 to <2:1 as communities aged in the absence of grazing.-from Authors

dc:title: Reproduction of Eriophorum vaginatum by seed in Alaskan tussock tundra.
dc:creator: Gartner B.
dc:description: Eriophorum vaginatum seedlings grew faster and survived longer on hepatic mats, followed by moss mats, than in other tundra microhabitats where competition from mosses and vascular plants or surface instability from frost heaving probably limit plant growth. Stimulation of germination by high temperature and light enables E. vaginatum to germinate well in disturbances.-from Authors

dc:title: Ecological studies on four rainforests in Karnataka, India. I. Environment, structure, floristics and biomass.
dc:creator: Rai S.
dc:description: The forests of 3 of the sites are species-rich with an important contribution from the Dipterocarpaceae but one has an almost monospecific dominance by Poeciloneuron indicum (Guttiferae). Total aboveground tree biomass was 420-649 t ha-1. The root fraction was 13.9-20.2 t ha-1. Girth increment data over 35 yr were available for one site and these were used with biomass estimates to calculate the approximate mean annual increase of aboveground and root (= or >5-cm girth) biomass in the four sites. These were 6.4-11.1 t ha-1 for aboveground material and 0.2-0.4 t ha-1 for roots. For small trees (= or <5 cm dbh) and herbs, the combined aboveground biomass was 7.2 t ha-1.-from Authors

dc:title: Density-dependence in Salvia lyrata, a herbaceous perennial: the effects of experimental alteration of seed densities.
dc:creator: Shaw R.
dc:description: Number of seedlings establishing varied widely from year to year. The half-life of the seedling population was c10 months and seedling mortality rate declined with time. Correlation of seedling mortality with population density was low. Established individuals significantly reduced the proportion of seedlings emerging and surviving. Seed density had no demonstrable effect on the proportion of seedlings emerging over a range of densities (0-1440 seeds dm-2). Seedling mortality depended strongly on seed and seedling density. Seedling growth was negatively density-dependent. Regulation of numbers of seedlings occurs primarily through the negative effects of adults. -from Authors

dc:title: Seed size variation in Desmodium paniculatum. II. Effects on seedling growth and physiological performance.
dc:creator: Wulff R.
dc:description: Differences in seed weight are due to differences in the amounts of reserve substances. Seedlings from larger seeds produce longer roots than those from smaller seeds and are able to emerge from greater depths of soil. Seed size is positively correlated with cotyledon area and weight, leaf area, root weight, and overall seedling dry weight. Overall carbon gain and water-uptake capacity are proportional to seedling size. With reduced water availability, the advantage of seedlings from large and small seeds depends on whether they are grown singly or in competition. Seedlings from larger seeds were favoured over those from smaller seeds during the early stages of growth in a drier, more disturbed, site.-from Author

dc:title: Regenerative potential of Elymus farctus from rhizome fragments and seed.
dc:creator: Harris D.
dc:description: Both newly-germinated seedlings and shoots from single-node rhizome fragments of sand couch grass could emerge after experimental burial with sand at a depth of 127mm, but not from 178mm. Multi-note fragments had a greater probability of emergence than single-node ones at any depth, and also could emerge from greater depths. Inhibition between buds on multi-node fragments led to reserves being concentrated into a single dominant shoot. Distal buds were more likely to become dominant than proximal buds. There were seasonal variation in the ability of nodes to produce roots and shoots under controlled conditions. Multi-node fragments are more flexible in their response to burial, because the likelihood of viable shoot production is increased and buds and resources are conserved against the possibility of further disturbance, whereas seed germination is an all-or-nothing gamble. -from Authors

dc:title: Revegetation of artificial disturbances in grasslands of the Serengeti National Park, Tanzania.
dc:creator: Belsky A.
dc:description: The effects of disturbance-depth and grazing on succession, spatial heterogeneity and species revegetation patterns were investigated. All disturbances were revegetated by species of the original community and returned to their previous compositions 1-3yr after disturbance. After elimination of grazing, short and sexually-reproducing species disappeared from the short- and mid-grass communities, which became dominated by tall, vegetatively-reproducing species. The mosaic and tall-grass communities were unchanged. Vegetation on the disturbed plots in both grazed and ungrazed blocks resembled the species composition and structure of the surrounding undisturbed vegetation. Within-treatment plot heterogeneity increased over 5yr in a community that was dominated by vegetatively-spreading species but decreased in communities dominated by caespitose species. Patterns of colonization and succession in the undisturbed plots supported Gleason's 'individualistic' concept.-from Author

dc:title: Litterfall and decomposition processes in the coastal fynbos vegetation, south-western Cape, South Africa.
dc:creator: Mitchell D.
dc:description: For communities of Leucospermum parile and Thamnochortus punctatus annual litter production was 84 and 72 g m-2 during 1981-82 and 1982-83 respectively with summer-autumn the main period of litterfall; the major litter came from the ericoid elements. Mean annual litter production under canopies of L. parile was 357 and 429 g m-2 during 1981-82 and 1982-83, respectively with 51-58% being leaf litter. Female plants of T. punctatus had an annual litter production of 23 g m-2 compared with 12 g m-2 for males. The main litter category from both sexes was inflorescence parts. Turnover times of dry mass were 14.5 and 11.4 yr for leaf litter of L. parile and sterile culms of T. punctatus, respectively; male flowerheads of T. punctatus showed no significant decay. -from Authors

dc:title: Population and community processes in a mosaic grassland in the Serengeti, Tanzania.
dc:creator: Belsky A.
dc:description: The Andropogon greenwayi community in the Serengeti Plains is a stable, two phase mosaic, consisting of a densely-vegetated Andropogon phase dominated by the mat-forming grass. A. greenwayi and a sparsely-vegetated Chloris phase consisting of a species-rich mixture. Both the mosaic and Andropogon greenwayi disappear when large herbivores are excluded. Long-term stability of the mosaic depends on the positive feedback of water infiltration and plant density, truncation of succession by grazers and browsers, compaction of the soil by large herbivores and the ability of the predominant plant species to colonize disturbances within their own phase. -from Author

dc:title: The phenology of Pythium ( Peronosporomycetidae) in soil.
dc:creator: Ali-Shtayeh M.
dc:description: There is a winter peak and summer trough of Pythium propagule availability although there is some evidence for a secondary peak in late winter. -from Authors

dc:title: The architecture of a deciduous forest canopy in eastern Tennessee, USA.
dc:creator: Hutchison B.
dc:description: The greatest leaf-area density was in the overstorey canopy where the (one-sided) leaf-area index (L) was >3.5. The lower canopy strata contributed slightly over 1 additional unit, yielding a total L of c4.9 for the stand. The silhouette-area index of woody biomass was c.0.6. Thus, the total plant-area index of this forest was c5.5. The mean area of individual leaves increased from the forest floor to midcanopy and decreased in the upper canopy. Generally, the mean dry weight of leaves increased with height, although some decline was observed in the uppermost portion of the canopy. The increase with height in mean leaf dry weight per unit of surface areas was much more uniform than that of mean leaf dry weight.-from Authors

dc:title: Topographic variation in the abundance of Hieracium floribundum: relative importance of differential seed dispersal, seedling establishment, plant survival and reproduction.
dc:creator: Reader R.
dc:description: The perennial herb Hieracium floribundum was found less often at the bottoms of small depressions (1-4 m diameter and 0.5-1 m deep) than at the tops in an abandoned pasture in Ontario. More wind-dispersed seeds landed at the top of depressions (9300 m-2) than at the bottom (4100 m-2). Topographic position had little effect on seedling establishment within a particular habitat type, but the best habitat type for seedling establishment (bare soil) was more abundant at the top of depressions (6.7-26.4%) than at the bottom (0.4%). Consequently, seedling establishment would be more likely to occur at the top of depressions. -from Authors

dc:title: A bioassay to determine the limiting minerals for seeds from nutrient-deprived Senecio vulgaris plants.
dc:creator: Fenner M.
dc:description: The most limiting elements Ni the seeds from the glasshouse parents were Ca and N, the least limiting S and Fe. Seedlings are more dependent on an external supply of certain mineral nutrients than others in the initial stages of growth.-from Author

dc:title: Ecological studies on four rainforests in Karnataka, India. II. Litterfall.
dc:creator: Rai S.
dc:description: The range of the mean annual total small litterfall was (in t ha-1 yr-1) 3.44-4.18 and that for leaf litterfall was 2.88-3.60, the lowest values recorded from evergreen tropical forest of large stature. All the sites except one had a seasonality of litterfall with high weights during the dry season. The chemical composition of the litterfall showed large differences between sites, particularly in P concentration. Mg concentration was generally high; samples from 2 sites had the highest concentration of this element recorded from tropical forest litterfall. Individual woody species varied in their time of leaf fall. Large monthly variations in the chemical composition of the litterfall may be related partly to the contribution of the different species.-from Authors

dc:title: Distribution of epiphytic bacteria on freshwater plants.
dc:creator: Baker J.
dc:description: Nasturtium officinale and Veronica beccabunga had significantly larger populations on the abaxial surfaces of their submerged leaves than on the adaxila surfaces of the same leaves, perhaps due to the unilateral release of hydroxyl ions during bicarbonate utilization. The older the leaf the greater was the bacterial density. The aerial parts of floating and emergent plants had substantially lower bacterial densities than the submerged parts. No significant seasonal differences were discernible between leaves of the same age, but significant short-term changes were detected on Ranunculus penicillatus var. calcareus.-from Authors

dc:title: Organization of vegetation mosaics in the Acacia schaffneri- Opuntia streptacantha association, southern Chihuahuan Desert, Mexico.
dc:creator: Yeaton R.
dc:description: Within each mosaic there were representatives of species occupying three distinct microhabitats: a perennial legume at its centre; an erect (shrubby or arborescent) form of platyopuntia near or under the legume; and a decumbent form of platyopuntia at the periphery). One of 2 species occupies each of these 3 microhabitats. The 2 species of each pair are separated from one another altitudinally over the 200-m gradient on the hillside studied. At least one species, Opuntia streptacantha, is involved in a temporal replacement of Acacia schaffneri.-from Authors

dc:title: Soil nitrogen and the role of fires as a mineralization agent in a South African coastal fynbos ecosystem.
dc:creator: Stock W.
dc:description: Fire is an effective mineralizing agent in soils of the coastl fynbos and has substantial effects on the concentration, form and distribution of the low N reserves.-from Authors

dc:title: Seed size variation in Desmodium paniculatum. III. Effects on reproductive yield and competitive ability.
dc:creator: Wulff R.
dc:description: For plants grown singly seed size had no effect on date of flowering or on weight of seeds produced, but plants from smaller seeds produced more seeds than those from larger seeds. Growth at high densities delayed flowering and reduced seed number without affecting seed weight. Plants derived from smaller seeds flowered later than those derived from larger seeds. If grown in pure stands, plants from smaller seeds attained a higher dry weight at maturity than those from larger seeds. Plants derived from larger seeds, when grown in competition with those from smaller seeds, showed a higher total reproductive yield.-from Author

dc:title: Seed size variation and pollinator uncertainty in Ipomopsis aggregata ( Polemoniaceae).
dc:creator: Wolf L.
dc:description: Up to 5-fold seed size variation occurred within both population and single plants. Seed size was negatively related to seed number per fruit within and among fruits in most plants. Seed number was directly related to the number of pollen grains deposited on individual stigmata. Seed size variation is influenced largely by pollinator effectiveness which determines the division of local resources among the seeds.-from Authors

dc:title: A comparative study of the influence of drought stress on flowering in Urtica dioica and U. urens.
dc:creator: Boot R.
dc:description: Flowering occured earlier in U. urens and was maintained at intensities of drought which strongly inhibited reproduction in U. dioica. This difference coincided with lower xylem water potentials and higher mortalities in U. urens and is consistent with plant strategy theories relating life-history and reproduction to frequency of habitat disturbance.-from Authors

dc:title: Factors limiting seasonal growth and peak biomass accumulation in Eriophorum vaginatum in Alaskan tussock tundra.
dc:creator: Shaver G.
dc:description: The seasonal peak in whole-plant E. vaginatum biomass is closely regulated by whole-plant nutrient content. Amount of growth achieved per unit area of ground within a growing season (net production) is regulated mainly by nutrient reserves at the start of the year and by uptake after mid-July. Carbon supply does not limit the total amount of seasonal growth, but it may affect the rate at which the seasonal peak biomass is reached.-from Authors

dc:title: The allocation of minerals to seeds in Senecio vulgaris plants subjected to nutrient shortage.
dc:creator: Fenner M.
dc:description: K, Ca and Fe were consistently less concentrated in the seeds than in the shoots. N, P and S were consistently more concentrated in the seeds. Mg was more concentrated in the seeds only in the three treatments with the lowest nutrient supply. The fraction of the plant's total content of any one element which was allocated to its seeds varied widely. In contrast to the constant proportional allocation of biomass to the seeds, the allocation of minerals to them incresed with nutrient shortage except in the case of Fe.- from Author

dc:title: The impact of a pathogen ( Puccinia lagenophorae) on populations of groundsel ( Senecio vulgaris) overwintering in the field. II. Reproduction.
dc:creator: Paul N.
dc:description: In control populations, the first capitulum buds were produced in late February. Onset of flowering became progressively delayed as status within the hierarchy declined. In all sub-classes of the population, rust infection during the previous autumn delayed flowering in the spring by 1-2 wk. The percentage of plants within a sub-class that were reproductive (bore buds or capitula) in the March and April declined as status in the hierarchy decreased. In classes of comparable status, fewer plants flowered in inoculated populations. Infection resulted in no significant change in the percentage of florets that developed into seed or in the viability of seed. The potential seed production of control populations was >460 000 seeds m-2. Populations that had been rust-infected in the autumn potentially produced 183 000 seeds m-2, a reduction of >60% compared with controls. -from Authors

dc:title: Sulphate in bog waters: a comparison of ion chromatography with Mackereth's cation-exchange technique and a revision of earlier views on cause of bog acidity.
dc:creator: Gorham E.
dc:description: Coloured organic anions are measured along with sulphate by Mackereth's technique. Inferences made earlier by Gorham, concerning sulphuric acid as a major cause of acidity in pristine bogs, are invalid. -from Authors

dc:title: The raised bogs of south-eastern Labrador, Canada: classification, distribution, vegetation and recent dynamics.
dc:creator: Foster D.
dc:description: Concentric raised bogs occur at low altitudes along the southern coast, excentric and plateau bogs extend inland to slightly greater altitudes and higher latitudes, and patterned fens occupy most of the interior north to the tundra. The zonation is explained in terms of the effects of moisture surplus, soligenous water flow and physiography on mire development. Raised bogs are similar to oceanic mires, with an extensive ground cover of Cladonia spp., absence of trees on the mire expanse, and pronounced surface patterns of broad peat hummocks and open-water pools. Three floristic noda are recognized in the phytosociological table: C. stellaris-C. rangiferina-Kalmia angustifolia nodum on raised hummocks and Sphagnum rubellum-Scirpus cespitosus and Sphagnum lindbergii- Scirpus cespitosus noda in hollows. As a result of the extensive cover of lichens the hummock vegetation readily burns during lightning fires, which are prevalent on the uplands. The recent history of the hummock vegetation involves alteration of Cladonia stellaris and Sphagnum fuscum.-from Authors

dc:title: Environmental controls over carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus fractions in Eriophorum vaginatum in Alaskan tussock tundra.
dc:creator: Chapin F.S.
dc:description: Growth rate of E. vaginatum in Alaskan tundra is probably controlled mainly by the availability of internal nutrient reserves rather than by any effect of temperature upon synthesis or transport of organic-carbon compounds required for growth. In spring, internal nutrient reserves from stems support a near-maximal growth rate. In late summer, growth slows because nutrient accumulation in stems takes precedence over its incorporation on growth. If nutrient availability increases in late summer, continued growth is possible, because the nutrient demands of both storage and growth can be met.-from Authors

dc:title: Seed size variation in Desmodium paniculatum. I. Factors affecting seed size.
dc:creator: Wulff R.
dc:description: In a population of Desmodium paniculatum seed weight varies by a factor of c4. Increase in temperature during the growth of the plants, reduces nutrient and water availability, and shortening of the photoperiod decreases the mean seed weight. A 50% reduction (to mimic grazing loss) in total leaf area during seed development increases mean seed weight of plants grown at high temperatures. Within a plant, seed size may vary by as much as a factor of two if grown under high-nutrient supply, but this variability is significantly reduced if plants are grown with limited nutrients. Part of the within-plant variability is due to the production of fruits with a variable number of seeds and to the position of the seed within a fruit. Seedlings from different positions within the fruit have different probabilities of survival. In plants grown with low (but not with high) nutrients, parental seed sizes are positively correlated with offspring seed sizes.-from Author

dc:title: Chemical defences in aquatic plants.
dc:creator: Ostrofsky M.
dc:description: In 15 species of aquatic vascular plants the alkaloid content ranged from 0.13mg g-1 dry weight in Heteranthera dubia to 0.56mg m-1 dry weight in Potamogeton crispus. These concentrations are within a range which serve as potential deterrents to herbivory.-from Authors

dc:title: Strandline colonization by Elymus farctus in relation to sand mobility and rabbit grazing.
dc:creator: Harris D.
dc:description: A catastrophic storm surge (January 1978) entirely removed the strandline communities at Holkham National Nature Reserve, Norfolk. Recolonization by Elymus farctus was rapid. Seeds (caryopses) and rhizome fragments were of very similar importance as propagules in founding new clumps; seeds and rhizome fragments also contributed similarly to the overall tiller densities found in a colonizing population. Subsequently sand couch grass maintained a significant but tenuous presence in the strandline. Tillers were frequently killed by deep burial in sand, or swept away after erosion by wind or waves. Foredune populations were much more secure and reached higher (X) tiller densities, but were subject to intense rabbit Oryctolagus cuniculus grazing for much of the year. Sand accretion and erosion were greatest between February and May when winds fast enough to move sand were predominantly onshore or along-shore. Inflorescence and seed production were poor: in the foredunes this was because of grazing pressure; but in the strandline flowering was even worse, because tillers rarely survived for >1 season to become vernalized. Populations of E. farctus in the strandline appear to be dependent on repeated colonization by seed and rhizome fragments from the foredunes.-from Authors

dc:title: Net primary production, decomposition and export of Spartina anglica on a Suffolk salt-marsh.
dc:creator: Jackson D.
dc:description: An annual net primary shoot production (ANPPs) for S. anglica of 220 and 280 g C m-2 was recorded in 1979 and 1980 respectively. Root production was estimated at 180 and 230 g C m-2. Shoot turnover was c2.1 yr-1, and periods of growth and senescence overlapped to a large degree. Only 5-10% of S. anglica stems reached flowering maturity. Total stem density was maximal in late summer (>2000 m-2 in September 1980). Live shoot biomass also reached a peak in late summer, >150 g C m-2 in both years. Production of leaves and stems was highest at the seaward edge of the salt-marsh. A loss of dead material equivalent to 29-32% of ANPPs per year was estimated due to microbes and micro-fauna, with an additional loss of c3% ANPPs yr-1 due to meiofauna. About 15-20% yr-1 of ANPPs was exported from the site of production as particulate matter; of this, 70% entered the estuary and the remainder was removed to the strandline.-from Authors

dc:title: Late- Holocene vegetation and coastal processes at a Long Island tidal marsh.
dc:creator: Clark J.
dc:description: Vegetation changes at the core sites included xeric Quercus-Castanea-Carya forests with a Pteridium-heath understory, followed by more mesic Fagus-Acer assemblages. Nyssa and a shrub transition zone subsequently invaded and were replaced by high marsh. At one of the core sites, a Typha marsh followed the shrub transition zone and was replaced by Phragmites. Fossil spectra from periods when inlets were open to the sea had high Salicornia, Atriplex, Foraminifera, and hystrichosphere percentages and the presence of Limonium pollen. These taxa disappeared simultaneously when the inlet closed, and the marsh was invaded by Cyperaceae and shrub assemblages. -from Author

dc:title: Seasonal and observer differences in vascular plant records from British woodlands.
dc:creator: Kirby K.J.
dc:description: Variations between vascular plant lists produced from the same wood by different observers, at different seasons and using different methods are described.-from Authors

dc:title: Litter decay and leaching from the forest floor in Pinus contorta ( lodgepole pine) ecosystems.
dc:creator: Yavitt J.
dc:description: The dynamics of organic matter and nutrient elements in the forest floor of Pinus contorta spp. latifolia forests in Wyoming were investigated by combining 3 related measurements: leaching of the forest floor; long-term decay of leaf litter; and steady state residence times in the forest floor. About 30% of annual C release from the forest floor resulted from leaching of organic compounds. Over 20% of the leaching flux for Ca and Mg was attributed to release from 0l litter, compared with <10% for K. High amounts of organic-N leaching from forest-floor layers, combined with rapid accumulation in 0- 8-yr-old litter, indicated rapid translocation of N from subsurface layers to 0l litter via heterotrophs. Leaching of polyphenols from the forest floor was 50% lower than the apparent loss from 01 litter, suggesting chemical transformation and changes in solubility of these compounds during litter decay.-from Authors

dc:title: Annual root growth and intraspecific competition for a desert bunchgrass.
dc:creator: Nobel P.
dc:description: The ground area explored by roots (the rooting area) was determined for 3 sizes of plants of Hilaria rigida in monospecific stands. Over a 4yr study period, the rooting area of small, medium and large plants increased by an average of 17% in undisturbed sites but by 125% when the adjacent vegetation was removed. Similarly, for 9 plants in undisturbed sites, with number of living culms increased by 7% over the 4yr period, and by 151% when the adjacent vegetation was removed. Rooting area, root length, root dry weight and shoot dry weight increased proportionally when the potentially competing vegetation was removed, most of the year-to-year variations being accounted for by variation in the number of days that the soil was wet (soil water potential >-3MPa in root zone). Because of the relative lack of growth of all plant sizes in undisturbed monospecific stands of H. ridiga, the spatial arrangement of plants must be quite constant in time. Where adjacent vegetation was removed, 106 wet days per year were required to maintain the existing rooting area, while for every additional 4 wet days the ground area explored by the roots increased by approx 1%. Thus, H. rigida can respond opportunistically to loss of competitors by expanding its rooting area. -from Authors

dc:title: Factors controlling the growth form of Spartina alterniflora: feedbacks between above-ground production, sediment oxidation, nitrogen and salinity.
dc:creator: Howes B.L.
dc:description: The relationship between above-ground biomass of Spartina alterniflora and sediment oxidation status (Eh), available ammonium concentration and interstitial salinity was investigated in a New England salt marsh. Sediment Eh gave the best prediction of above-ground biomass. The relationship between sediment oxidation and above-ground production existed between years and marshes. -from Authors

dc:title: Demographic responses of Bromus tectorum and seedlings of Agropyron spicatum to grazing by small mammals: occurrence and severity of grazing.
dc:creator: Pyke D.
dc:description: The impact of grazing by Microtus montanus and Peromyscus maniculatus (Cricetidae) upon the demographies of the alien annual Bromus tectorum and seedlings of the native perennial Agropyron spicatum was invesgitated in a meadow-steppe community in E Washington. Cricetid populations were highest between late winter and early spring; the M. montanus population increased >2-fold between the 1st and the 2nd year of study. Most grasses (c60%) emergent from winter until early spring were grazed at the time of the peak in the M. montanus population. Most (c80%) of the grazed individuals had >75% of above-ground vegetation removed. Plants from autumn- and winter-emergence cohorts were grazed more severely than spring-emergent plants. Survival of B. tectorum was not influenced by grazing in either year, whereas A. spicatum cohorts grazed in late winter had significantly higher mortality than cohorts of the same age that were simultaneously protected from grazing. For B. tectorum, biomass and seed production declined significantly as the severity of grazing increased. For A. spicatum, there was no significant relationship between grazing severity and biomass.-from Author

dc:title: Pollen transport and deposition by bumble bees in Erythronium: influences of floral nectar and bee grooming.
dc:creator: Thomson J.
dc:description: Bombus bifarius was a much less effective pollinator of Erythronium grandiflorum than was the larger B. occidentalis. Numbers of pollen grains deposited by bumble bees on the stigmata of E. americanum vary greatly from flower to flower. Time spent by a bee on a flower is positively related to nectar concentration and volume. Flowers with large volumes of nectar receive more pollen grains per visit, presumably because visits are longer. Most deposition of grains from a particular donor flower occurs on the first several recipient flowers subsequently visited by the bee, but a few grains travel much farther. Pollen carryover in E. grandiflorum is reduced by bee grooming. The negative effect of grooming on carryover is increased when the recipient flowers have undehisced anthers. Erythronium americanum and E. grandiflorum were similar in carryover, but Linaria vulgaris showed much higher carryover.-from Author

dc:title: Effect of drought during different stages in the life-cycle on the growth and biomass allocation of two Aira species.
dc:creator: Rozijn N.
dc:description: Drought treatment in the vegetative phase had no effect on growth in the reproductive phase in either species. In the reproductive phase Aira praecox grew exponentially, while A. caryophyllea did not grow. Biomass allocation showed greater differences between the species than between treatments, especially in the reproductive phase. The proportion of biomass allocated to reproductive organs was affected by drought treatment. Production of caryopses was reduced by drought if it occurred in the vegetative as well as in the reproductive phase. A. caryophyllea seems better adapted to reproduction in a habitat with a restricted growing season, while the continued vegetative growth in the reproductive phase of A. praecox increases its survival during drought. Its continued vegetative growth may lead to a higher reproductive yield. While A. caryophyllea is mainly adapted to a growing season of which the duration is restricted by drought, A. praecox is better adapted to drought itself. For that reason A. praecox can be expected to occur in drier sites in a dune habitat.-from Authors

dc:title: Architecture and growth strategies of tropical trees in relation to successional status.
dc:creator: Shukla R.P.
dc:description: Crown architecture, growth and branch display were studied in two early-successional (Anthocephalus cadamba, Duabanga sonneratioides) and two late-successional (Artocarpus chaplasha, Dillenia pentagyna) tree species of subtropical humid forest in NE India. While the early-successional species conform morphologically to Massart's (D. sonneratioides) or Roux's model (A. cadamba), the late- successional species conform to Scarrone's (D. pentagyna) or Rauh's model (A. chaplasha) of tree architecture. Faster growth over a longer annual-growth period results in the sparse branch arrangement in early-successional species which facilitates greater leaf exposure. The slower growth rate over a shorter growth period results in densely packed canopies with mutual shading of leaves of late-successional species.-from Authors

dc:title: Seasonal changes in carbon fractions in Alaskan tundra plants of differing growth form: implications for herbivory.
dc:creator: Chapin F.S.
dc:description: Stems of deciduous shrubs (Salix pulchra, Betula nana) and forb (Rubus chamaemorus) showed well-developed over-winter carbohydrate storage, with concentrations increasing in autumn and declining in spring, coincident with initiation of leaf and root growth. The evergreen shrub (Ledum palustre) showed little seasonal fluctuation in carbohydrates of stems and old leaves. The graminoid (Eriophorum vaginatum), which had an intermediate amount of over-wintering green leaf biomass, showed seasonal carbohydrate, fluctuations in stems intermediate between those of evergreen and deciduous shrubs. Among mosses, Aulacomnium spp. showed greater seasonal fluctuation in carbohydrate concentration of brown material than did Polytrichum/Pogonatum spp. Preferences of each of 8 generalist herbivores (vertebrate and invertebrate) for the study species correlated positively with N, P and K, and negatively with lipid and cellulose contents. The similarity of preference ranking suggests that characteristics of the plant material exert primary control over patterns of food choice by these generalist herbivores. Preference ranking of Lemmus (brown lemming), a specialist on graminoids and mosses, correlated positively with fibre and negatively with mineral nutrient contents.-from Authors

dc:title: Patterns of change in the carbon balance of organic soil- wetlands of the temperate zone.
dc:creator: Armentano T.
dc:description: Disturbance of carbon storage in organic soil-wetlands of the temperate zone has been analysed for the last 200 yr and considered in relation to other sources of atmospheric CO2 from the biopsphere. Storage before recent disturbance is estimated at 57-83 Mt C yr-1, >9M of this in boreal peatlands. The total storage rate, lower than previous estimates, reflects accumulation rates of carbon of only 0.20 t ha-1 yr-1 and less in the boreal zone where 90% of temperate organic soils are found. Widespread drainage of organic soil-wetlands for agriculture has significantly altered the carbon balance. A computer model was used to track the consequent changes in the carbon balance of nine wetland regions. Drainage reduced or eliminated net carbon sinks, converting some wetlands into net carbon sources. Different regions thus can function as smaller carbon sinks, or as sources, depending on the extent of drainage. In either case a shift in carbon balance can be quantified. Regional differences are noted. The aggregate shift in the carbon balance of temperate zone wetlands, when added to a far smaller shift from tropical wetlands, equalled 150-185 Mt of carbon in 1980 and 5711-6480 Mt since 1795. Despite occupying an area equivalent to only 2% of the world's tropical forest, the wetlands have experienced an annual shift in carbon balance 15-18% as great.-from Authors

dc:title: Invasion of forest floor space, clonal architecture, and population growth in the perennial herb Clintonia borealis.
dc:creator: Angevine M.
dc:description: Clintonia borealis (Liliaceae), studied in the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest, New Hampshire, has underground rhizomes which persist for up to 15 yr, allowing precise determination of the number and position of ramets, the branching and elongation pattern of rhizomes, and the amount of floor occupied by each clone during each of the previous years. Rosettes only produce 1-2 new rhizome segments each year, and each segment has one bud. Cones invade a wedge-shaped section of the forest floor, moving from a point of branching at an initial rate of 6 cm yr-1 decreasing in later years to 2 cm yr-1. The branching frequency and angle of orientation of new rhizomes result in the perimeter of the wedge (the distance across all ramets present in a year) to increase at a constant rate of 8.3 cm yr-1. There is much between-clone variation in the rate of invasion of the forest floor, caused by the interaction of genotype and microhabitat differences with the basic morphological plan.-from Authors

dc:title: Past peat cutting and present vegetation patterns in an undrained fen in the Norfolk Broadland.
dc:creator: Giller K.
dc:description: Recent (19th Century), shallow (60-8cm depth) peat cutting (turf ponds) occupy about half of the fen surface. Several community types (Cladietum marisci, Cicuto-Phragmitetum, Phragmites-Sium/Typha communities, Peucedano-Phragmitetum cicutetosum and P.-P. caricetosum) are restricted to turf ponds. The Peucedano-Phragmitetum caricetosum is very species-rich and of great conservation importance, but occupies only small areas of turf ponds. Patterns of turf-pond recolonization are analysed, and 4 main seres are identified, mostly different from those around the broads. Only one (Cladium sere) leads to Peucedano-Phragmitetum caricetosum vegetation. It is restricted to some marginal turf ponds in places not over clay deposits. The florisitc differences between the herbaceous vegetation of the former peat workings and the uncut surfaces are probably largely a result of their different hydrological regimes and associated differences in redox potentials and redox-related variables.-from Authors

dc:title: From swamp to lake: recent changes in a lowland tropical swamp.
dc:creator: Osborne P.
dc:description: Aerial photographs show freshwater vegetation changes since the 1950s in Waigani Lake close to Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea. Records of diatom assemblages and plant seeds in sediment cores confirm that the lake was at one time dominated by a mixed emergent swamp, that this was replaced by floating-leaved plants and that the latter were replaced by the present open water.-from Authors

dc:title: Influence of climate and age on annual shoot increment in Salix herbacea.
dc:creator: Wijk S.
dc:description: Shoot age accounted for 39-48% of the within-shoot variation in length of the annual stem segments, which showed a logarithmic decline throughout the life-span of the shoot. Climatic variables contributed little to the total variation in annual increment, but temperatures during the intense snow-melt period (May/June) during the year before growth, accounted for c80% of between-year variation in 2 of 3 samples. This suggests that growing season length limits the carbohydrate stores available for the following year's shoot increment. -from Author

dc:title: Testing for life historical changes in spatial patterns of four tropical tree species.
dc:creator: Sterner R.
dc:description: For 3 of the species, the spatial models which fit the adults were more uniform than the models which fit the juveniles. The adults of these species were significantly more uniformly distributed than expected from the random mortality of their extant juveniles. The 4th species had adults with a similar distribution to randomly thinned extant juveniles. Post-germination survival leads toward a uniform distribution. During the lifespan of 3 of the species, repulsion occurs between individuals. At small scales, clumping, when present, may be more the result of patchy dispersal of seeds or seedling germination than the patchy survival of germinated individuals.-from Authors

dc:title: Plant communities of the Shetland Islands.
dc:creator: Roper-Lindsay J.
dc:description: Sixty-five noda were identified and their general characteristics described. These noda were assigned to both recognized and new taxa within 17 phytosociological classes. A new association of grazed low altitude blanket bogs, the Empetrum-Rhytidiadelphus loreus Association is outlined. While climatic and topographic interactions on the flora have determined the natural vegetation communities, the impact of land-use, particularly grazing has been to confine these communities to areas inaccessible to sheep. Most of Shetland's vegetation composition had been determined by grazing. -from Authors

dc:title: Mycorrhizal infection in grasses of Kenyan savanna.
dc:creator: Newman E.I.
dc:description: Root samples of 5 grass species, distributed over 4 soil types, were collected. All samples, including those from seasonally flooded sites, had vesicular-arbuscular mycorrhizal infection. In the main collection in November, near the start of the wet season, infection was lowest on a freely drained soil low in organic matter, apparently due to a decline in mycorrhizas since the end of the previous wet season. Speed of development of an effective mycorrhizal system early in the wet season may be important for savanna grasses. -from Authors

dc:title: Mycorrhizas in Zambian trees in relation to host taxonomy, vegetation type and successional patterns.
dc:creator: Hogberg P.
dc:description: Thirteen species of common Zambian trees were found to be ectomycorrhizal and 10 endomycorrhizal. The ecological groups of species suggested as typical of the successional stages from open fire-degraded chipya woodland to closed dry evergreen mateshi forest via miombo woodland, show differences in the occurrence of mycorrhizas. In the chipya group, endomycorrhizal tree species predominate and ectomycorrhizal species are sparse. Ectomycorrhizal Uapaca spp invade chipya woodland, and later provide cover for the regeneration of ectomycorrhizal genera forming the miombo group - Brachystegia, Isoberlinia, Julbernardia and Monotes - and for ectomycorrhizal Marquesia of the mateshi group. In the mateshi forest group, there is a mixture of ecto- and endomycorrhizal tree species.-from Authors

dc:title: Regulation of submerged aquatic plant distribution in a uniform area of a weedbed.
dc:creator: Anderson M.
dc:description: Total biomass and the biomass of the most abundant species were related to sediment nutrient concentrations in both areas. No relationships were found between species distribution and sediment characteristics. Nutrient shortage prevents competition in these areas and allows coexistence of many species.-from Authors

dc:title: Effects of coppicing on the growth of oak timber trees in the Bradfield Woods, Suffolk.
dc:creator: Bridge M.C.
dc:description: Growth in diameter of standard oak trees is increased by a measurable, though small, degree by temporary removal of their surrounding underwood by coppicing. This effect is demonstrable for at least 9 yr following coppicing. The tree-ring chronology for the Bradfield Woods can be cross-matched with those of several other oak chronologies in the British Isles. -from Authors

dc:title: Distribution of potential macrofossils in Lake Dobson, Tasmania.
dc:creator: Hill R.
dc:description: Most species present in the vegetation surrounding Lake Dobson were recovered as leaves from the lake sediment, but the proportions of species changed rapidly between samples, and an accurate reconstruction of the surrounding vegetation from these samples would be impossible except in terms of species present. Epacris serpyllifolia, a small, lakeside shrub, was overwhelmingly dominant in most sediment samples, and was strongly over-represented in relation to its importance in the surrounding vegetation. Eucalyptus coccifera, the dominant canopy tree species, was common directly below overhanging trees, but as the leaves sank rapidly they were virtually absent from the rest of the lake. The most important features affecting leaf deposition in the lake were the prevailing wind direction, the presence of lakeside or overhanging vegetation, and leaf sinking rates.-from Authors

dc:title: Hydrology, water chemistry and ecological relations in the raised mound of Cowles Bog.
dc:creator: Wilcox D.
dc:description: The Cowles Bog National Natural Landmark and the wetlands between the dunes near the S shore of Lake Michigan, in Indiana, contain plant species that are typical of circum-neutral fens. The distribution of 8, rather sharply delineated, vegetation types correlates most strongly with water level variations resulting from the presence of a 4.1ha convex peat mound. -from Authors

dc:title: The effect of competition on the structure and dynamics of Acacia savannas in southern Africa.
dc:creator: Smith T.M.
dc:description: Acacia nilotica trees whose neighbours within a 5m radius were removed showed a significant increase in both stem diameter increment and shoot extension. Seedling establishment relative to canopy cover was examined in both A. nilotica and A. tortilis communities. Two 'types' of species were apparent: 1) seedling establishment associated with under-canopy environments, and 2) seedling establishment restricted to open or between-canopy environments. There was a significant positive relationship between slope of the nearest-neighbour regression and both available water capacity and total exchangeable bases in A. tortilis sites. -from Authors

dc:title: Biomass allocation and phenological differences among southern and northern populations of the C<inf>4</inf> grass Echinochloa crus- galli.
dc:creator: Potvin C.
dc:description: Resource allocation was compared for reciprocal transplants of Echinochloa crus-galli from Quebec, North Carolina and Mississippi. Home transplants always allocated more energy to reproduction than any others. Plants from Mississippi failed to flower in Quebec. Those from Quebec did not survive the North Carolina summer. The southern populations are increasingly selected against in Quebec as the season progresses. -from Author

dc:title: The impact of a pathogen ( Puccinia lagenophorae) on populations of groundsel ( Senecio vulgaris) overwintering in the field. I. Mortality, vegetative growth and the development of size hierarchies.
dc:creator: Paul N.
dc:description: A few, small plants sustained very high rust infections. They had smaller leaf areas than larger individuals but the same number of pustules per plant. As a result of severe winter weather, all plants lost leaves and decreased in shoot dry weight. Losses were of similar absolute magnitude in all plants but were relatively more damaging to small plants. High death rates among those plants inoculated in the autumn were attributed to infection of the hypocotyl, which almost invariably killed the host within 1-2 wk. Heavy infection compromised the capacity of plants to tolerate winter stresses. Small, rust-infected plants were severely injured by conditions early in winter which did not harm control plants of comparable size. In control populations, vegetative regrowth in the spring was rapid until reproduction began. Flowering was delayed in inoculated populations and rates of vegetative growth were greatest in the individuals that had suffered least winter injury. -from Authors

dc:title: Successional communities of plants and phytophagous Coleoptera.
dc:creator: Brown V.
dc:description: At Silwood Park, Berkshire, the successional communities of phytophagous beetles are characterized by a sequence of dominant species, with the highest dominance occurring during very early colonization and mid-late succession; a pattern also seen in the herbs. The species diversity of herbs and weevils is closely related throughout the succession. Plant-species composition may be more important than plant structure in solely phytophagous groups of insects. The host-plant associations of weevils and leaf beetles are discussed in terms of generalism-specialism and niche breadth. Occurrence of a higher degree of generalism in weevils in late succession, than predicted in certain models of succession, is explained in terms of Rhoades' and Cates' theories of plant anti-herbivore chemistry. -from Authors

dc:title: Tree-fern skirts: a defence against climbers and large epiphytes.
dc:creator: Page C.
dc:description: Retention of dead fronds as a fringing 'skirt' around the trunks of tree-ferns may deter climbing plants from penetrating the crown, where the expanding fronds are particularly susceptible to damage. Skirts also prevent the establishment of large, potentially damaging epiphytes on the part of the trunk nearest the crown.-from Authors

dc:title: The genetic and environmental control of reproductive timing in a short-lived monocarpic species Daucus carota ( Umbelliferae).
dc:creator: Lacey E.
dc:description: Offspring rosette size and recent growth rate were both good predictors of year of flowering. An increase in size but a decrease in relative growth at the end of the summer were associated with an increased probabilty of flowering in the next season. Annual maternal plants and high nutrients produced both the largest offspring and the greatest number of annuals. Also, the maternal contribution acted directly upon the year of flowering as well as indirectly through size and recent growth. Both genetic variability and habitat heterogeneity explain the variation in year of flowering in natural populations. Results provide evidence that the early-rosette growth rate and the length of the pre-reproductive period are negatively correlated, as predicted by theories about the evolution of life-history patterns. Rapid growth may help annuals to persist in habitats which generally favour biennials. Response to nutrient supply did not vary among maternal age groups as might be expected in colonizing species. This suggests that phenotypic plasticity in response to nutrient supply evolves independently of year of reproduction.-from Author

dc:title: Seasonal nitrate reductase activity of three genotypes of Atriplex canescens in the northern Chihuahuan Desert.
dc:creator: Sisson W.B.
dc:description: Seasonal nitrate reductase (NR) activity of the young, uppermost leaves of diploid, tetraploid and hexaploid genotypes of Atriplex canescens showed maximal activity during reproductive growth. Because rainfall coincided with reproductive growth, higher NR acticity during this period may have been due to new leaf growth and increased soil-NO3- availability rather than an increased need for N due to developing seeds. The wing-like bracts of the immature fruits possessed NR and may have been a source of reduced N for seeds. Seasonal leaf water content was significantly correlated with NR activity in all genotypes; water potentials in the stem xylem were correlated with NR activity only in the tetraploid plants.-from Authors

dc:title: Germination of ten shoreline plants in relation to seed size, soil particle size and water level: an experimental study.
dc:creator: Keddy P.A.
dc:description: Seeds of Acorus calamus, Alisma plantago-aquatica, Bidens cernua, B. vulgata, Cyperus aristatus, Lythrum salicaria, Polygonum punctatum, Sagittaria latifolia, Scirpus americanus and Typha angustifolia were vernalized and sown along a particle-size gradient. Two water levels, 1 cm and 4 cm below the soil surface, were provided. In the drier treatment, 9 out of 10 species germinated differentially along the gradient. In the wetter treatment, only 3 out of 10 species so responded. In both wet and dry treatments, species which did respond significantly to the gradient had a shared preference for the fine soil, except Acorus calamus in the dry treatment. The species with the smallest seeds generally showed the greatest response to the gradient. Large- seeded species therefore had the broadest tolerances for variation in soil particle sizes. On lakeshores, the fine particles associated with sheltered bays would allow the highest recruitment irrespective of seed size. These effects would be most pronounced during periods of low water. Zonation of adult plants is not produced by species with different-sized seeds requiring soil particle sizes for maximum germination.-from Authors

dc:title: Vegetation pattern and diversity in SE Labrador, Canada: Betula papyrifera (birch) forest development in relation to fire history and physiography.
dc:creator: Foster D.
dc:description: Betula papyrifera forests range in size from <1 ha to several km2, display sharp borders with the adjoining conifer forests and are restricted to steep slopes that have burned in the previous 110 yr. The community is distinguished from conifer forests by the presence of 14 differential species, by the scarcity of terrestrial cryptogams and by development of a diverse understorey of vascular plants. Three minimum conditions are necessary for B. papyrifera forest development: moist and well-drained soils, a nearby seed source, and an open site, the last largely created by lightning fires. Following fire, regeneration by B. papyrifera is rapid and results in the formation of an even-aged overstory. Gradual invasion of canopy openings by Picea mariana and Abies balsamea results in progressive conversion to conifer forest.-from Authors

dc:title: Ecology and evolution of self-pollination in Arenaria uniflora ( Caryophyllaceae).
dc:creator: Wyatt R.
dc:description: Plants are pollinated chiefly by syrphid flies and andrenid and halictid bees, which are abundant even in those areas where self-pollinated morphs predominate. It is hypothesized that the stimulus for the evolution of self-pollination in A. uniflora was competition for pollinators. Arenaria glabra, another winter annual endemic to rock outcrops in the south-east USA, is pollinated by the same flies and bees as A. uniflora but has a larger, showier floral display. Wherever A. glabra grows together with A. uniflora, it is the self-pollinated morphs of the latter that occur.-from Author

dc:title: Ferrous iron and phototrophy as alternative sinks for sulphide in the anoxic hypolimnia of two adjacent lakes.
dc:creator: Davison W.
dc:description: In the shallower lake (Priest Pot, <4 m), light penetrated to the hypolimnion and there supported photosynthetic bacteria that oxidized sulphide to sulphate. Iron sulphide therefore failed to form in the water column, but was formed in the sediment from the high concentrations of dissolved components in the pore water. In the deeper lake (Esthwaite Water, 15 m), light was attenuated within the oxidized epilimnion. This precluded photographic oxidation of sulphide and allowed simple chemical formation and sedimentation of FeS.-from Authors

dc:title: Effect of neighbouring trees on eucalypt growth in a semi-arid woodland in Australia.
dc:creator: Penridge L.
dc:description: Neighbourhood effects on Eucalyptus populnea were studied in Queensland. A competitive-interference model used leaf area as a measure of plant size which is related to resource demand. This measure reflects important functional variables such as water uptake, litter input, root volume and shading, and can be applied to different growth forms.-from Authors

dc:title: Nitrogen and phosphorus availability in treefall gaps of a lowland tropical rainforest.
dc:creator: Vitousek P.
dc:description: Nitrogen availability (net N mineralization) was extremely high in a lowland rainforest on volcanic soil at La Selva, Costa Rica, averaging 50-80 mu g g-1 month-1 (822 kg ha-1 y-1). Available P concentrations were relatively low (2.5 mu g g-1). Nitrogen mineralization did not increase in the crown-fall zone of treefall gaps, although the possibility of a short-lived increase immediately after treefall could not be ruled out. Phosphorus concentrations increased slightly but not significantly (to 3.3 mu g g-1). The root-throw zone of treefall gaps had significantly lower N mineralization and P concentrations than the crown-fall zone or the zone along the fallen trunk. Low nutrient availability in the root-throw zone could select for colonizing species distinct from those establishing in other zones of treefall gaps. -Authors

dc:title: Control of relative abundance of perennials in chalk grassland in southern England. I. Constancy of rank order and results of pot- and field-experiments on the role of interference.
dc:creator: Mitchley J.
dc:description: Study of the relative abundance of perennial species in chalk grassland in S England revealed great constancy in rank order: across any one site (20 stands of 0.48m2 in an area of 3480m2), from year to year (1980-82) and between 2 sites 150km apart. Experimental data suggest that the control of relative abundance in chalk grassland involves steady state relationships between species with taller (and more widely-spreading) and shorter individuals, and between species with longer- and shorter-lived individuals. The balance between species is largely determined by frequency of timing of grazing and by frequency of regeneration from seed. -from Authors

dc:title: Local distributions of old-field and woodland annual plant species: demography, physiological tolerances and allocation of biomass of five species grown in experimental light and soil- moisture gradients.
dc:creator: Cid-Benevento C.
dc:description: Summer-flowering old-field annuals do not extend into the often adjacent disturbed woodland areas because the old-field annuals do not allocate enough biomass to reproduction at the low light levels typical of the disturbed woodland environment, to produce enough seeds to allow for population replacement. Summer-flowering woodland annuals do not colonize old fields due to physiological intolerance of light and soil-moisture conditions in some areas in the old field, as well as other unexamined factors (but not pattern of biomass allocation). Differences between old-field and woodland annuals in shoot and root architecture, rather than percentage biomass allocation, appear more likely to explain the restricted distribution of these woodland annuals. -from Authors
